awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Tapping Hidden Potential: Multilevel Factors that Improve the STEM Outcomes of Racial Minorities, and Youth with Lower Socioeconomic Status or a Disability Classification
awd_abstract_narration:
This Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) grant will establish an integrated research and education program focused on questions underlying persistent underrepresentation of racial minorities, youth with lower socioeconomic status (SES), and disability classifications in STEM fields. In general, there is a lack of clear direction for addressing these disparities. The project aims to promote understanding of the conditions under which racial minorities, persons with disabilities, and persons with low SES are full participants in STEM fields.  This effort is consistent with broader NSF goals of broadening participation and expanding efforts to increase participation from underrepresented groups in STEM fields. Youth in these underrepresented groups have lower average levels of achievement and face cultural and socioemotional barriers to STEM-positive attitudes and choices. This project advances knowledge by incorporating a focus on structural and institutional contributors as well as individual attitudes and choices, and by moving beyond establishing disparities to quantifying factors most closely implicated in STEM disparities.

This project's research efforts will use quasi-experimental techniques to analyze data on over 23,000 9th graders from the nationally representative High School Longitudinal Study of 2009 to answer these questions: 1) How do 9th graders' STEM potential and STEM learning environments vary at the intersection of race, SES, and disability status? 2) Which student, classroom, and school characteristics contribute the most to disparities by race, SES, and disability status in STEM outcomes? 3) Which classroom and school characteristics improve STEM outcomes for students who began high school with similar levels of STEM potential? Measures describing students, courses, parents, teachers, and schools enable a nuanced consideration of STEM potential and potential confounders. Data will be analyzed using factor analysis, decomposition analysis, multilevel modeling, and propensity score matching. This project's education goals are to: 1) form and lead a Data Scientists Undergraduate Work Group, 2) increase STEM internships, particularly those that involve data analysis, for Portland State University (PSU) students, 3) initiate and facilitate a Big Data and Big Problems Interdisciplinary Research Group for PSU faculty and graduate students, and 4) increase research and STEM knowledge through research assistantships and the integration of research findings into PSU courses taught by the investigator.

The CAREER program is a National Science Foundation (NSF)-wide activity that offers awards in support of junior faculty who exemplify the role of teacher-scholars through outstanding research, excellent education, and the integration of education and research within the context of the mission of their organizations. This award is supported by EHR Core Research (ECR) which emphasizes fundamental STEM education research that generates foundational knowledge in the field.

por.por_cntn:
Statistical research on the neurodevelopmental disabilities common across children—ADHD, learning disabilities, autism—long employed a medical rather than social lens of disability. The medical lens problematically eclipses the structural inequities and biases that increase incidence or perception of these disabilities, inconsistencies and subjectivities in how these disabilities are classified, and social consequences of labeling a child as disabled. This project integrates a social model of disability with sophisticated statistical methodologies to understand the STEM outcomes of youth at the intersection of their disability status, race, and socioeconomic status. We have published 11 articles in high-tier peer-reviewed journals, and have 3 studies under review and 5 more in progress. These studies have received awards from the American Sociological Association’s Disability in Society Section and Race, Gender, and Class Section. One was invited to be featured as a blog post on SAGE Perspectives Blog for Disability Pride Month.   I received Portland State University’s Junior Faculty Research Excellence Award in 2018.

This project’s findings have important implications for educational policy. We demonstrate how students are classified with disabilities on the basis of subjective and diagnostically irrelevant characteristics. We show how the costs of special education may outweigh the benefits, dampening students’ educational progression, their self-efficacy, and their teachers’ expectations for them. We delineate how disproportionate placement in special education is in largest part a function of the racial disparities in achievement that result from structural racism. The policy implications that arise from these studies include not using special education to resolve racial disparities in achievement, and exercising caution in using disability labels and special education to meet the learning differences of students of any race. We should be transparent about the scientific limitations of these diagnostic processes, so that children and their educational trajectories are not defined by subjective labels. In the center of the continuum from medical to social, we legitimize the experiences and challenges people with disabilities experience and empower them to choose the aspects of their label that are resonant and that improve their life experience. The impact of these studies is magnified through dissemination of findings in non-academic venues and directly to policymakers.

This project’s findings advance disability research methodologically and theoretically. The intellectual merit of this project’s work is increased by using nationally representative and longitudinal data, transdisciplinary theories and literatures, and the innovative integration of intersectional theories alongside statistical approaches. In addition to demonstrating the importance of understandings of disability that are not based on White youth or higher socioeconomic youth, I introduced the new perspective of ‘increased liability’ to be used in conjunction with the widely employed perspective of ‘multiple marginalization’ in intersectional research. We also call on all researchers focused on inequality to recognize disability as a key axis of stratification, with disability ideology fundamental in the social construction, legitimation, and perpetuation of other dominant axes of stratification (e.g., class, race, gender). With disability in higher education particularly under-studied, I crafted a theoretical frame to understand how and why perceptions and experiences of educational disabilities shift between K-12 schooling and higher education, documenting tensions between disability ideology and dominant US educational ideals of merit, individual accountability, and standardization.

CAREER awards support faculty members who exemplify the role of teacher-scholar through the combination of outstanding research and education. I developed and facilitated an interdisciplinary quantitative methods research group, Quantitative Data Analysis to Improve the Lives of Youth (QDAILY) that attracted presenters and attendees from across PSU and the city from 2017 through 2020.  I taught an Interpreting Statistics workshop every summer between 2017 and 2020 for undergraduates in BUILD EXITO and Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation (LSAMP). In broadest impacts, my research group, the Career Analysts, has met on a weekly basis since 2017, benefiting society by preparing future STEM education researchers. This group has served 1 postdoctoral fellow, 26 graduate students, 2 postbaccalaureate students, and 12 undergraduate students. In addition to receiving training in research, many participants of the Career Analysts have received training in writing funding proposals. Despite PSU being an R2, my advisees secure tenure-track positions, research analyst positions at universities and in the public sector. In part through experiences and connections that resulted from this award, I contribute to PSU’s research infrastructure in multiple ways. We secured additional funding to support our research and students from the Spencer Foundation, Sloan Foundation, and the Oregon Department of Education via Oregon State University. I am a facilitator for PSU’s Sloan Center for Systemic Change, which involves institutionalizing infrastructure across ten doctoral programs at PSU to improve recruitment, admission, and retention of domestic Black, Indigenous, and Latine doctoral students in the physical sciences and engineering. I facilitated the Research Pathways program for early career faculty at PSU in 2023 and continue to lead a monthly writing group for early career faculty at PSU.
